date_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 21, 2023
comment: First off, these glasses are great: they are sturdy, a hefty weight, and have a nice, smooth lip. However, they were packaged terribly. Each glass was in its own bubble wrap baggie, which was a good start. But then the glasses were just thrown into a box - no cardboard dividers or additional protection. Moreover, the box they were packed in was too big to accommodate the glasses snugly. So, not surprisingly, the glasses shifted around in transit and several arrived broken. At least the bubble wrap baggies prevented the shattered glass from spilling all over the inside of the box, but that‚Äôs really the only positive thing I can say about the packaging. So, if you‚Äôre lucky and your glasses arrive intact, you‚Äôll be very happy with your purchase. But assume you‚Äôll realistically only end up with 9 usable glasses out of 12.

overview_text: Strongly remind us of dollar store glasses
comment: These glasses are just ok.  They are pretty, but they definitely not high quality and and remind me of something I've seen at the dollar store.  There is a detectable seam which distracts from the beauty of the patterned glass.  They are slightly smaller than expected and might make nice votive holders.  I did put them on the top rack of the dishwasher and they came out fine. (UPDATE: we now know why you shouldn't (?) put them in the dishwasher: the rose colouring gets removed! (See my picture.) Of course, one might consider that an improvement....)I personally don't find the rose-coloured ones all that attractive, though my wife likes them a bit more than I do. Beauty in the eye of the beholder, and all that...

date_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 2, 2023
overview_text: A step short of hobnail heaven
comment: The good:- clear ones are dishwasher safe- I like the hobnails (I probably like the feel of the hobnails more than I like drinking out of the cup..is that normal?)- truth in advertising; they look pretty much exactly like the pictures.- they are almost the same size on the top as they are the bottom; less chance of tipping.The meh:- Apart from several other reviews I read, I do NOT think they are well balanced and sturdy.  To me, something about the proportions are just slightly off-putting.  I think the design somehow equates with a thicker gauge glass in my brain.  I imagined that they were going to be thick-walled and heavy-based (they are standard-walled and standard-based), but when I took it out of the box and hefted it around, it seemed, if anything, a little middle-to-top-heavy.  I tossed it to my wife and she gave it a quizzical look and sort of had the same response.  I felt good that it wasn't just me being hyper-critical, but there is also a very high chance that we are both drinkware snobs.All in all they seem like a standard-grade juice glass with some cool hobnails.  Ones that would be fine, as the description states, for a hostess gift or a gift for new home owners.  I could see them being used as juice glasses for a weekend brunch, or cups that are a good size for kids to fill up and not waste half a glass of milk like mine do.  But on the same token I would be hesitant to let them use these all the time because I don't want them to get broken and lose all my precious hobnails.

date_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 2, 2022
overview_text: Pretty for the price. Durable? Eh...
comment: Purchased these after much reviewing and after our first set of similarly styled glassware from a Bullseye-Themed Competitor, hoping that this would be a step up. The verdict 6 months later: ....meh?They look and feel miles better than the starter set you'd pick up at the store. The bottom is significantly weightier, helping with stability on a surface and when you hold it in your hand. They don't cloud up, even in our old grandpa of a dishwasher. This set is probably intended for more everyday use (which is how we're using it), but it's a classy enough style that you'd feel comfortable serving up a fancy drink or two.That is, of course, if you have a full set remaining by the time your guests arrive. Over the last six months, we've lost a good three of the eight taller glasses due to chipping in the dishwasher and the occasional crack if you tap them against another glass accidentally stacking them in the cupboard. Turns out these are less durable than a toothpick. The shorter glasses have fared better than their older siblings; maybe it's an issue with the strength in the middle of the glass?This is disappointing, especially considering the reputation Libbey has for glassware. I know that it's glassware we're talking about here, not WWE fighters, so I know you have to be a little more careful with them. But alas, I was hoping to get a stronger set this time around. Long story short, if you're going to go with this set, expect to buy your replacement in a year or so. (Or sooner!)

date_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 9, 2022
overview_text: OK standard drinking glass, but surprising little bumps of glass on rims
comment: The glasses are OK and more-or-less as expected.  General, serviceable, not-glamorous drinking glasses that are OK to hold, seem to be dishwasher safe, and hold a decent amount liquid.  The surprising negative thing is that several of the glasses have a pronounced bump out on the drinking rim where the glass "dripped" during the molding process.  The sort of thing you see when paint drips on an edge.  There is just one bump on each the glasses where this occurs, but it is surprising that these glasses got thru quality control (if there was any).  You could expect at some point in the future that the bump will get knocked-off and then there will be a cut hazard for users of these glasses.  They'll just have to be thrown away when this happens.

overview_text: Don't buy in advance for gifting
comment: We bought 24 Pavina glasses in advance as a housewarming present. Our friends found that two came broken, and Bodum would not replace them, even though they were new/unused/in-box. If you buy these, please know that the official return policy states that Bodum must be notified of breakage within 5 business days and that the return window is 30 days. date_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 9, 2023

The second glass has a hairline chip inside the rim of the glass causing condensation in between the glass panes. Unfortunately, we won‚Äôt be able to use these two glasses anymore. We gave a 3-star rating because we like the product but we are disappointed because our first shipment had broken glasses and had to be returned/replaced. Now our second shipment has 2 damaged glasses. With the price of the product and the fact that it is glass, we would have expected higher quality or at least better protection since it was being shipped. Might be better to purchase from a store vs having it shipped.

comment: I purchased the short version of these a few months ago and put them in the dishwasher and all seemed to be fine.  Then I got the tall ones and within a week one had enough water inside to actually slosh in the bottom and a second one had several misty areas on the sides.  Then I noticed that two of the original  short ones had developed the misty areas all about the size of a thumb print.  I contacted the manufacturer, sent them pictures they requested with replacements promised.  Then I was notified that quality control claimed the one with all the water was not their product.  It definitely was but they only replaced the 2 short ones and 1 tall one. I resent pictures to show the markings were identical with their new replacement but I never heard back again.  The glasses do keep condensation from forming and damaging wood furniture but they MUST be hand washed to prevent water from getting inside.

overview_text: Rough outer top lip seal when you drink
comment: We had the 12oz for almost two years and loved them...still do.  We finally got these 16oz versions to match and there is everything we loved about the 12oz EXCEPT 6 of the 8 have very rough portions that pinch and annoy our lips if we drink from that portion.  We have to find the smoothest part to drink from on these 6.  We cannot simply return these as we had confidence in the company so we unpacked these, put our old 16oz glasses and tossed them out while we cleaned the new ones.  As I first started drying the glasses after washing I discovered the rough edges around the rim, where they seal it.  Again, none of the 12oz we got in 2018 have this challenge, they're all smooth to this day.  So, this may just be an unlucky couple of boxes that got through QC or the company's QC has gone down.  Not sure which and we are not going to buy another box to find out...these are not cheap and the investment is one we made gladly and now are simply frustrated with.  I hope it is just a couple of boxes.  This would have been a 5 star review, we like these a lot.  But, when 6 of 8 are rough to the lips every time you take a sip the review score drops.

date_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 20, 2017
overview_text: The glass design itself is fine - Quality control is what destroys this product
comment: The glass design itself is fine - Quality control is what destroys this product. I had actually cut my wrist open because there was a large part of the glass' base missing (broken) which I didn't see when opening and handling my new glasses. At first I thought that this blemish had to do with bad packaging - but when I looked at all the other glasses (4 total) EVERY single one had small (but significant) defects - a chip or broken part of some kind, mainly around the lips, where people put their lips on! It looks so bad that I now think they had left the manufacturing facility like that, and did not even receive these blemishes during the shipment process. I'm not sure, but when it comes down to it, this is what you get: Four broken margarita glasses, which your guests (whom you serve) may cut their lips or their wrists open on. Two stars might have been too nice. Once again, not entirely sure if it has to do with quality control or packaging, but the end product is the same.

date_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 14, 2023
overview_text: Doesn't work any better than a glass of ice
comment: There are two big problems with these. One is that there's not enough gel in the walls to reach the top of the cup when frozen. This means that the part of the liquid you're drinking from isn't actually being chilled if the cup is full. The other is the large opening. Because the walls are what is keeping the drink cold, the large open top allows a lot of heat transfer to occur which warms your drink fast. Precisely calibrating the amount of gel to fill the whole cup when frozen and fitting a lid on top would drastically improve this product.

After contacting Libbey directly they were nice enough to send me some replacement cases of glasses which too had many defective glasses. When I contacted them AGAIN telling them that even the replacement glasses had defects in most of them I was told to only purchase their glasses through a 'b2b' vendor and not Amazon as the quality control thru Amazon was not the same. So I have been highly disappointed that not only is their quality control inconsistent, but I had to also scramble to get replacement glasses from different other vendors to fulfill my customer orders. I just wanted to pass this info along to anyone else who may want to order these glasses thru Amazon.

If you even gently lay a pot or stack more than 2 plates on top of one of these in the sink...they break.  If you barely tap them...they break.  If your dishes shift in the sink from filling up with water...they break.  Do not buy these if you have kids.  Do not buy these if you are even moderately rough with your glassware. date_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 15, 2019
overview_text: Disposable glassware -- Is that what you want?
comment: [Here's an update of my comments below.  The glasses are breaking less often now.  That's because there are fewer of them left unbroken to break.  Down to two or three glasses left.  They frequently break when placed in the dishwasher; some break when being removed from the dishwasher.  So far none have broken just when sitting on the counter in an empty room.]These are attractive glasses.  Problem is they break easily.  I've had them for less than one month. So far, half of the larger size glasses have broken.  Some have broken when I put them in the dish washer; some when I've taken them out.  The good news is none of the smaller glasses have broken yet.  The bad news is I haven't yet used any of the smaller glasses.  Some are in the cabinet untouched; others are still in the box.  So, evidently the key to long life for this glassware is to keep it in the box unused.  It's not expensive, so if you think of these as much like disposable plastic drinking glasses,  you'll do fine.  I note though that in my experience, disposable plastic drinking glasses are much sturdier.

comment: I've had a set of Libbey glasses of the same type for over 5 years. A few of them broke eventually, so it became time to seek out replacements but I loved the style. The numbers might not look like much, but the difference is huge. The tall glass now feels incredibly fragile and cheap.Old tall glass weight: 13.7 ozNew tall glass weight: 10.2 ozOld short glass weight: 11.2 ozNew short glass weight: 9.9 ozThe inside of the new glasses are also incredibly tilted on the bottom! While this doesn't impact the functionality (it's a glass.. it holds liquids) it looks bad, and speaks to the install manufacturing quality. I don't expect these to be sturdy long term, and one of the short glasses broke in transit (but I just needed the tall glasses, so no biggie).The included pictures show the new glasses with tilted bottoms on the left, old glasses on the right.I would have paid more to get glasses of the same quality as my old set. overview_text: Warranty service turnaround time is ridiculous.
comment: Love the 24 oz tumblers but not sure they are of great quality. I've had 2 of these and both of the seals where the pieces are put together both came apart. Sent them both in for warranty repair in what I thought was plenty of time for my receiving them back by Thanksgiving. They were received by them on Sept 18th. Thirty something days past when I reached out to them to inquire about there status. Their reply was that it took up to 45 days and to check my tracking to see when they received them and count days from there. We'll, 50 or so days past without hearing anything, so I reached out again and was told it could take up to 60 days and that same look at my tracking thing. Today Nov.24 has been a week or so over the 60 days, so I reached out again and now am told it can take up to 90 days and that same check my tracking thing. This either boils down to, 1. They are extremely shorthanded or the do produce a quality product and are overwhelmed in the warranty dept. Either way, they had better get a handle on it or others are going to follow in my footsteps and look fir a better quality tumbler company.

date_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 2, 2019
overview_text: Not Like The Tervis Cups I Know And Love
comment: I am a Tervis devotee. I got rid of all my glassware and now use only Tervis 16oz tumblers at home. They are just amazing! They are not just leakproof and sweat proof, they also insulate brilliantly.But I‚Äôm disappointed to report that this 24oz tumbler was nothing at all like the Tervis tumblers I have grown to love. It was so preposterously inferior, in fact, that I asked Amazon for a refund. It was sweat proof and leakproof but there was no insulation at all. To illustrate the difference I will give two examples:The insulation on my 16oz Tervis tumblers is phenomenal. Many times and in all seasons I have set one of my 16oz Tervis tumblers full of ice next to my bed at night (with no lid) and woke up in the morning to find ice cold water with chunks of ice still floating in it. I‚Äôve also left a cup full of ice in a hot car in the summer, locked it up and gone shopping for an hour, and still had lots of ice left in the cup when I returned.By comparison, while it did not leak or sweat, there was essentially no insulation in this 24oz Tervis tumbler. Even the lid didn‚Äôt help. I filled the 24oz Tervis tumbler with ice and set it by the bed while I was reading and within a couple of hours all the ice was melted and the water was only slightly cool. This happened time and time again. I couldn‚Äôt believe this cup was made by Tervis because it sure didn‚Äôt perform like the Tervis products I know. I‚Äôd planned to show it off to my grandchildren, who use Yeti products, but I was too embarrassed by its poor performance.

date_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 20, 2017
overview_text: The glass design itself is fine - Quality control is what destroys this product
comment: The glass design itself is fine - Quality control is what destroys this product. I had actually cut my wrist open because there was a large part of the glass' base missing (broken) which I didn't see when opening and handling my new glasses. At first I thought that this blemish had to do with bad packaging - but when I looked at all the other glasses (4 total) EVERY single one had small (but significant) defects - a chip or broken part of some kind, mainly around the lips, where people put their lips on! It looks so bad that I now think they had left the manufacturing facility like that, and did not even receive these blemishes during the shipment process. I'm not sure, but when it comes down to it, this is what you get: Four broken margarita glasses, which your guests (whom you serve) may cut their lips or their wrists open on. Two stars might have been too nice. Once again, not entirely sure if it has to do with quality control or packaging, but the end product is the same.

The fourth broke after being tipped over on a table, which I guess makes sense, but given the other three breakages, it's worth including here.We had these on our registry because my partner's parents had Libbey glasses of a similar style that have lasted for decades. I told him that I filled the glasses with water all the way to the top and then measured how much water was in the glass. The amount varied between 7.5 and 8 ounces. Josh told me I measured incorrectly and they were 10.25-ounce glasses. I told Josh I used to work in a calibration lab and was familiar with weight and volume measurement. Josh told me I was still wrong. (So much for ‚Äúthe customer is right‚Äù.) I will be returning the glasses. ‚ÄúGreat Customer Service?‚Äù

date_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 2, 2024
comment: I bought a set that looked similar at a big box store decades ago and bought this hoping to fill in the gaps of glasses broken over the years. At first I was thrilled: design is almost a perfect match, aside from the base being inexplicably slightly thicker. Then I noticed the lip.It's impossible to see in the glamor shots, but the lips of these are...bad. Wobbly and inconsistent like the machine that made them was drunk. There's supposed to be a raised ridge around the edge, and this ridge is wildly inconsistent: sometimes full height, sometimes half, sometimes flush with the glass. The remaining glasses in the set I was trying to replace have none of these issues. I'd understand if it was one odd duck out, but ALL the new glasses have this issue. I also felt some rough spurs of glass one the rims when examining them, which...yikes. Combine this with the reports of these easily and unexpectedly breaking (I've had, and dishwashingmachine'd the old set for years without issue) and it's clear the quality control on these is garbage. May try a replacement set to see if I get lucky, but otherwise, no joy.

date_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 11, 2023
comment: I'm sorry to say that my experience with the Host Freeze Beer Glasses has not been very positive. While the glasses are marketed as a convenient and innovative way to keep beer cold, they fall short in several areas.Price: The Host Freeze Beer Glasses are priced at a premium, but unfortunately, the product's performance does not justify the cost.Delivery Speed: Shipping was fast, but the glasses arrived with a few cracks and chips, suggesting poor quality control during manufacturing or shipping.Product Quality: The quality of the glasses is disappointing, with flimsy plastic that easily cracks or breaks with regular use. The double wall and freezer gel features do not work as advertised, as the glasses do not keep beer cold for very long and the gel can leak out and make a mess. Additionally, the glasses are smaller than expected, making them impractical for larger portions or thicker beer.Comparison to Similar Product: Compared to other beer glasses with cooling features, this product falls short in terms of durability and performance.Seller's Response Times: The seller was unresponsive to inquiries and did not offer any assistance with the quality issues or shipping damages.Ease of Use: While the glasses are easy to use and clean, their poor quality and lack of performance make them not worth the investment.Conclusion: Overall, I would not recommend the Host Freeze Beer Glasses, as the quality and performance do not meet expectations. There are better and more reliable options on the market that are worth considering.

date_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 12, 2021
overview_text: Thin glass combined with thick base causes spontaneous breaking
comment: All of these glasses have now spontaneously broke.  To make matters worse, glass fragments have entered my dishwasher pump and caused it to fail.The glass is so thin it cools or heats up instantantly, whereas the think base retains heat or cool.  The variation causes the glass to break for many instances  1) In the dishwasher 2) When putting ice tea in it (even when glass is at room temperature to start with) or 3) simply sitting on my desk for an hour.

comment: We have a set of 4 of these same Mikasa old fashioned glasses that we bought 8 or 10 years ago. We liked them so much that we wanted to purchase another set to bring our total to 8. They cost a bit more than your average old fashioned glass, but that would be ok if they were the same quality that Mikasa had previously produced. These new glasses are basic and not worth the 40$ price tag they came with.You can purchase similar quality glassware that is much cheaper from other companies.We have had our original set for years, and they are in great shape. This new set from Mikasa is thin and fragile. Two of the glasses already broke within the first week of use. One broke when accidentally bumped by a crystal wine glass, and the other in the sink while being washed by hand.The photo provided shows the quality that Mikasa previously produced (on the right) and what I just received from them in this last purchase (on the left). You can clearly see that the glasses are significantly thinner and not as heavy or durable anymore.* I always wash our glasses by hand, but it should be noted that Mikasa also posts contradictory statements on their Amazon page about these glasses being "dishwasher safe", while also stating that they should be hand washed.I would not spend money on these ever again, let alone put them in the dishwasher.

comment: My husband and I received these without a card or receipt as a wedding present a little more than a month ago. I loved the pattern on the outside, so we bought several more sets of different glasses with the same pattern. I don't have a dishwasher, so these glasses have been gently hand washed in warm water. One night I opened my bar to get a glass out and noticed that one of the glasses had cracked all the way around. We threw it away, assuming it was a freak accident. A week later, the same thing happened to another one of the glasses. We're throwing away the other two for fear that it could happen while someone is drinking out of the glass. I called Mikasa and was told that they're very durable glasses and that it never happened. Reviews online say otherwise. I would not recommend these in a million years.

Again I contacted Amazon and they would not send a second replacement and my only option was to get a refund and then go back and reorder online.  But guess what? date_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 13, 2010
comment: My husband and I have had a set of mikasa cheers double old-fashioned glasses for the last five years.  We received them as a wedding gift.  We love them, my husband uses them for everything.  After five years of very regular use, being put in the dishwasher, and even dropped a few times, one of them broke.  It was my husband's favorite of the bunch, so I decided to order another set.  These are not the same glasses.  They may look the same in the picture, but the difference in quality is astounding.  The old glasses have thick, heavy bases and a substantial feel to them.  The replacements I ordered from amazon are just cheap - the glass is lighter at the bottom and very thin at the top, and the etching quality is nowhere near the same.  I was going to write and complain already, but then tonight, on the first use of one of the glasses, my husband put ice in it and it broke just from that.  As I pulled a second one out of the dishwasher to put it away, it was already broken.  So two of the four glasses have not even made it through one single use.  Unacceptable.  I'm requesting my money back.

overview_text: Don't buy these if you like your drinking glasses in one piece
comment: Garbage, that's what these are, literal garbage. I say that because that's where mine ended up. I'm 42, and I've have never had an issue with breaking glasses, mugs, plates, etc., but these glasses in particular are so easily broken that you have to be careful when washing them. That's right, I broke several glasses trying to clean them. How? Beats the heck out of me. They're just that flimsy. The rest fell over, either in the sink or on the table, shattering instantly. It wasn't like they were thrown to the ground- these were instances where my fingers nudged the top half of the glass just enough for it to tip over. After 15 months, I only have one of the eight taller glasses left, and five of the smaller glasses. I think I'm going to throw away the rest of them so I can avoid having to clean up broken glass later, because I know it's just a matter of time. Wish I could give this zero stars.

date_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 2, 2024
comment: I bought a set that looked similar at a big box store decades ago and bought this hoping to fill in the gaps of glasses broken over the years. At first I was thrilled: design is almost a perfect match, aside from the base being inexplicably slightly thicker. Then I noticed the lip.It's impossible to see in the glamor shots, but the lips of these are...bad. Wobbly and inconsistent like the machine that made them was drunk. There's supposed to be a raised ridge around the edge, and this ridge is wildly inconsistent: sometimes full height, sometimes half, sometimes flush with the glass. The remaining glasses in the set I was trying to replace have none of these issues. I'd understand if it was one odd duck out, but ALL the new glasses have this issue. I also felt some rough spurs of glass one the rims when examining them, which...yikes. Combine this with the reports of these easily and unexpectedly breaking (I've had, and dishwashingmachine'd the old set for years without issue) and it's clear the quality control on these is garbage. May try a replacement set to see if I get lucky, but otherwise, no joy.
